idef0.viewpoint: the management of process plant information throughout the life of a process plant.

page.title: Perform process plant life cycle activities - aggregate

activity.name: Perform process plant life cycle activities
activity.description: The completion of all tasks involved in the life cycle of a process plant from conception through final disposal.
activity.note: Major outputs from the life-cycle activities are contractual documents, regulatory compliance information, data retained beyond the life time of the plant, useful products generated by the operation of the plant, and residual materials remaining in the environment upon completion of the plant life cycle. These residual materials include waste products generated while producing the product or products and the disassembled plant.

page.title: Perform process plant life cycle activities - breakdown

activity.name: Manage and plan project
activity.description: Managing the project requires that sufficient resources be provided to execute the project and check that the execution is done in accordance with the plans and regulations. Planning the project is the activity that establishes a detailed technical plan and a financial plan that are consistent with the engineering, construction, and commissioning activities required to fulfill the project objectives.

activity.name: Design and engineer plant
activity.description: The activities required to develop an appropriations request and generate a construction design specification for some modification to an existing process plant or the construction of a new process plant.
activity.note: The appropriation request is submitted to company management for approval. Upon approval, the construction design specification is generated.

activity.name: Procure goods and services
activity.description: The process whereby needed plant items, equipment, or services are purchased or acquired.

activity.name: Construct and commission plant
activity.description: The process of building or retrofitting a physical plant, using plans and building materials. The layout drawings and material requirements are used to establish the physical arrangement and to procure the materials required. A plan for erecting the plant is determined from material schedules, heavy equipment schedules, labor schedules, and environmental conditions (such as weather). Temporary erection material (such as scaffolding) is procured as needed. Regulatory requirements and client requirements are used to plan and erect the plant, and for the final testing and certification for operation. The result is a completed plant that meets the testing procedures defined in the project control and approval documentation.

activity.name: Manage, operate, and maintain plant
activity.description: The activities required to manage, operate, and maintain the plant safely, efficiently, and according to operating procedures and regulations.

activity.name: Decommission and dispose of plant
activity.description: The activities during which the plant is decommissioned, disassembled, and the site either prepared for a new plant or returned to a state specified by the regulatory agencies. Records of the disposal of toxic and hazardous waste together with the location of any holes and the methodology used to plug them are produced and stored in accordance with approved procedures and guidelines.

activity.name: Control and approve activities
activity.description: Prepare plans, check conformance to plans, and arrange for any corrective actions.

activity.name: Provide resources
activity.description: Acquire and deploy personnel, tools, and funding to perform the project activities.

activity.name: Define procedures, standards, guidelines, specifications, and codes
activity.description: Specify the engineering policies to be used and determine appropriate procedures, codes, standards, guidelines, and specifications that may apply.

activity.name: Plan and analyze project finances
activity.description: The activity of anticipating and estimating the financial resource requirements for a project. This activity establishes the expected financial performance for the project and the project financial plan.

activity.name: Obtain agreements with regulatory bodies
activity.description: The activity of confirming that the intended design, construction, commissioning, operation, and decommissioning of the proposed project will comply with requirements of the regulatory body. This confirmation is recorded by formal documentation such as written agreements and safety compliance reports.

activity.name: Establish plant design basis
activity.description: The activity of collecting a complete and consistent set of constraints, requirements, and guidelines for subsequent engineering activities.

activity.name: Produce conceptual process design
activity.description: The activity of defining the basic parameters of a plant flow scheme.

activity.name: Produce conceptual plant design
activity.description: The activity of extending the conceptual process design into a preliminary plant spatial configuration.

activity.name: Produce final process design
activity.description: integration of conceptual process and plant designs to fully define parameters of a plant flow scheme.

activity.name: Produce final plant design
activity.description: The activities required to generate a construction design specification from the process plant requirements.
activity.note: The activities include designing the mechanical, electrical, and civil engineering systems of the process, designing the detailed instrumentation systems, producing piping and instrumentation diagrams and detailed equipment layout through isometric drawings or three-dimensional computer-aided design (CAD) models.

activity.name: Maintain suppliers list
activity.description: The process whereby a list of accepted or approved suppliers is kept up to date.

activity.name: Prepare bid packages and solicit bids
activity.description: The process whereby the technical and commercial requirements for a plant item are compiled and sent out for pricing by multiple suppliers.

activity.name: Evaluate bids and negotiate purchase
activity.description: The process whereby bid packages are evaluated, a supplier is selected, and an agreement is entered into for the acquisition of the plant item or items.

activity.name: Receive, inspect, and disposition components
activity.description: The process of receiving equipment and materials from various suppliers at the process plant, inspecting the equipment and material for compliance to the purchase specification, and either placing the equipment or material in stock, delivering it to construction or maintenance, or returning it to the supplier.

activity.name: Deploy component or service
activity.description: The process whereby the part or service is delivered and the acquisition agreement is fulfilled.

activity.name: Produce construction plans
activity.description: Using site drawings, layout drawings, and other documents, determine the desired sequence for building the plant that will meet contract budget and schedule. Determine those services that will be needed from sub-contractors for the site preparation, erection, and testing of the plant. Develop detailed erection drawings and schedules for each section of the plant and for temporary structures.

activity.name: Obtain construction services
activity.description: Use the construction plan as a requirements list for outside services needed and their schedule. Negotiate contracts and agreements with sub-contractors, equipment suppliers, and labour unions as needed for the erection of the plant. Adjust the schedule of the construction plan to allow for the availability of sub-contractors, equipment and labour.

activity.name: Erect plant
activity.description: Utilizing plans, materials, services and labor, build a physical plant that conforms to the detailed design.
activity.note: This process begins with the site preparation; grading and primary foundations poured, and temporary roads and rails created. Utility services are provided and temporary warehouses are built. Major equipment is moved, often in pieces, and installed on foundations with supporting steel. Site permanent buildings are built, as are pipe racks and other permanent steel. Pipe runs and pipe spools are put in place with valves and miscellaneous equipment and welded or joined. Other items such as ducting, electrical, instrumentation are installed.

activity.name: Produce as-built surveys
activity.description: The completed plant is given a physical inspection to determine whether the plant conforms to the detailed design. The detail design drawings and other documents are updated to reflect the changes to the plant discovered during the inspection.

activity.name: Pre-commission plant
activity.description: Resolve any differences between the detailed design and the as-built plant, perform all testing required by regulatory agencies and the client, resolve any problems that were discovered during testing, and obtain regulatory permission to start-up the plant for functional testing.

activity.name: Commission plant
activity.description: Test the functionality of the completed plant prior to operation, develop final operating and maintenance procedures, and obtain final regulatory approval to operate the plant.

activity.name: Manage plant
activity.description: Direct and administrate the operations, maintenance, and disposal of the plant.

activity.name: Operate plant
activity.description: Conduct and monitor the activities required to operate the plant.

activity.name: Maintain plant
activity.description: Conduct and monitor the activities required to maintain the plant.

activity.name: Decommission plant
activity.description: Plan and complete the activities required to decommission the plant.

activity.name: Dispose of plant
activity.description: Plan and complete the activities required to dispose of the plant.

activity.name: Identify and define unit operations
activity.description: Incorporate the design basis and owner requirements to define and document the basis for conceptual process design and estimated time and cost expenditures. If the design activity is related to an existing plant, then existing operations are incorporated into the conceptual process design

activity.name: Calculate heat and mass balance
activity.description: Calculations performed based on design basis, unit operations, fuel or materials in the process, along with associated chemical properties to optimize plant and operational cost.

activity.name: Identify and size equipment
activity.description: Identify equipment requirements based on the design basis and unit operations. Sizing of the equipment is based on the heat and mass balance calculations and unit operations.

activity.name: Establish initial process control logic
activity.description: Document philosophical and operational requirements between instrumentation, equipment and process.
activity.note: This activity results in the development of the design basis documents (see Design basis).

activity.name: Identify and analyze safety requirements and hazards
activity.description: Review design basis, unit operations, heat and mass balances, materials, identified equipment, control logic and process flow diagrams against federal, state and local regulations, codes and standards to determine compliance and produce an analysis of results.

activity.name: Produce process flow diagrams
activity.description: Production of a schematic showing basic process flow developed from the cumulative results of unit operations, equipment sizing, initial logic and safety requirements along with related chemical properties.
activity.note: If a design activity is related to a modification or addition to an existing plant, then the existing plant information is reflected in the developed process flow diagram.

activity.name: Identify plant performance requirements and establish design strategy
activity.description: Define a quantitative description of the quantity and quality of a product to be produced by the plant in a yearly time period and describe the major steps required to complete enough design to obtain a budget estimate for business calculations as well as to begin the identification of process unknowns.
activity.note: Performance requirements are usually stated as units of product per unit time.
Additional qualifications are typically made regarding the quality of the plant. Examples include time between major shutdowns for continuous processes, percent uptime required, and expected yield.

activity.name: Engineer and design plant systems
activity.description: At the conceptual level, this is a preliminary scoping of all major modifications or additions to major plant distribution systems such as steam, compressed air, electrical power, refrigeration, water, firewater, and sewers (storm, process, sanitary). Impact on distribution pipe lines and feeder systems quantity and size are also included. A consideration of system operation in terms of reliability, uptime, planned maintenance, and winter and summer operations are vital to proper planning.

activity.name: Engineer and design equipment
activity.description: Preliminary sizing of all major pieces of required equipment is made at this time with enough detail to obtain budget quotes.
activity.note: This includes equipment such as refrigeration machines, purchase power substations, secondary substations, switch gear, compressors, and boilers, as well as the major process equipment specific to the plant.

activity.name: Layout plant
activity.description: A general arrangement of the plant in plan view, showing all the major components of the distribution systems affected by the plant and the location of the plant. A general arrangement of all major equipment within the battery limits of the plant is also included.

activity.name: Produce conceptual safety engineering designs
activity.description: Create designs that specifically address how the major hazards associated with the new plant are to be dealt with to ensure the safety of all personnel working in the plant as well as the general site and surrounding neighbourhood population.
activity.note: These hazards will have been identified during the preliminary screening reviews to identify chemical, fire and health hazards associated with the specific chemical or mechanical characteristics of the process.

activity.name: Define plant operating philosophy
activity.description: Ascertain and confirm those plant operating characteristics and activities necessary to achieve the plant owner's operational goals such as methods of production, technology, plant safety, or plant availability. This activity includes selecting types and sequences of unit operations and processing steps so that the plant production objectives can be achieved and specifying alternate or abnormal operating conditions, and procedures such as startup and shutdown.

activity.name: Specify piping and instrumentation
activity.description: Define piping and instrumentation required by the process plant based on the functional requirements for the plant.
activity.note: Piping and instrumentation functional requirements are developed based on plant production capacities, process type or technology, control methodology, chemical content of process streams, and equipment layout. Also considered are alternative operating conditions, maintenance requirements, and plant operating and personal safety are issues. The results of this activity are detailed on P&IDs, line lists, equipment lists, and instrument lists.

activity.name: Specify equipment functional characteristics
activity.description: Define the functional characteristics of each major item of equipment based on confirmed plant operating requirements, process technologies, and process optimization.
activity.example: Functional characteristics include equipment type, process stream inputs, outputs, capacities, and conditions, equipment metallurgy, piping and instrumentation, power requirements, and auxiliary systems.

activity.name: Specify control requirements
activity.description: Define instrumentation and control system characteristics required to fulfill requirements for plant operation using the operating procedures and safety requirements.
activity.note: Control systems are used to help maintain plant safety, ensure product quality, and to safeguard equipment. These systems are used to control areas such as process reactions, flows, temperatures, pressures, and levels. They operate automatically, or provide indications to plant personnel. Control requirements are generally defined in the operating procedures and specified on the P&ID and in the instrument list.

activity.name: Specify safety requirements
activity.description: Perform a formal plant process design, operation, and control review to assess the whether all safety requirements are met.
activity.note: Plant safety requirements involve issues such as source terms for spill scenarios, vapour dispersion for combustible and toxic releases, reliability of metallurgy and other materials, component failure rates, operator response and error, fail-safe instrumentation, equipment spacing, number and size of equipment trains, radiation from fires, relief system design philosophies, deflagration test results, thermal runaways and associated vent sizing, detonations and resulting shock waves.

activity.name: Optimize for environment
activity.description: Evaluate the plant design against the applicable environmental regulations (Federal, State, and local) and modify the design where required.
activity.note: These regulations influence many of the activities in plant and process design such as operating procedures, plant and process control strategies, specification and design of piping, instrumentation, and equipment, as well as site selection. Broad regulatory interpretations often mean that conservative measures are incorporated in plant design.

activity.name: Finalize system design
activity.description: Develop the system design, expressed by flow and control information and equipment performance data, to its final state.
activity.note: The resulting design serves as a basis for detailed plant design.

activity.name: Finalize layout, arrangement, and spatial design
activity.description: Develop the spatial design of the plant to its final approved-for-construction state utilizing the finalized system design as the primary input.

activity.name: Specify building and plant services
activity.description: Establish utility and other service needs for the building(s) and plant(s) based on owner requirements, final system design, and final spatial design.

activity.name: Confirm safety and regulatory compliance
activity.description: Establish that the final design of the plant meets specified safety and regulatory criteria.

activity.name: Analyze final plant design
activity.description: Examine all aspects of final design for compliance to performance criteria and generate any necessary changes required to meet these criteria.

activity.name: Finalize plot plan
activity.description: Develop the arrangement design of main equipment, buildings and structures of the plant, to its final state.
activity.note: The plot plan is usually expressed by plan view only.

activity.name: Finalize layout
activity.description: Develop the detail arrangement design of equipment, buildings and structures of the plant, to its final state.
activity.note: The layout is usually expressed by both plan view and elevation view.

activity.name: Finalize structure
activity.description: Develop the structure design of the plant to its final state.

activity.name: Finalize HVAC
activity.description: Develop the HVAC design of the plant to its final state.

activity.name: Finalize electrical, instrumentation and control
activity.description: Develop the design of electrical, instrumentation and control of the plant, to its final state.

activity.name: Finalize piping details
activity.description: Develop the special and prefabrication design of piping of the plant, to its final state.

activity.name: Finalize piping routes
activity.description: Develop the piping route design of the plant to its final state.
activity.note: The piping route is usually expressed by plan view only.

activity.name: Finalize 3D piping details
activity.description: Develop the 3D piping detail design of the plant to its final state.

activity.name: Finalize piping prefabrication
activity.description: Develop piping prefabrication design of the plant to its final state.
activity.note: The resulting design serves as the essential data for procurement and fabrication of piping prefabrication.

activity.name: Fabricate prefabricated piping
activity.description: Receive order and input raw materials and produce inspected spool pieces for installation in a plant.

activity.name: Prepare prefabrication piping
activity.description: Prepare all piping materials and documents that are necessary for piping prefabrication.

activity.name: Prefabricate piping
activity.description: Utilizing piping materials and documents, manufacture spool pieces.

activity.name: Inspect prefabricated piping
activity.description: Examine and analyze prefabricated piping for manufacturing defects in accordance with inspection procedure.

activity.name: Ship prefabricated piping
activity.description: Finish, pack and load spool pieces, to ship to a plant site. Usually shipping units are specified by purchaser day by day, or week by week, so as to correspond to site installation work schedule.

activity.name: Make production schedule
activity.description: Develop a time-based list of production tasks.

activity.name: Procure piping materials
activity.description: Purchase or acquire necessary piping materials that are used for prefabricating piping assemblies.

activity.name: Receive piping materials
activity.description: Process the receipt of the necessary materials, by the piping prefabricator, that are used for prefabrication of piping assemblies.

activity.name: Cut pipe
activity.description: Execute an operation or series of operations to divide a straight pipe into pieces in accordance with the lengths specified in piping prefabrication documents.

activity.name: Prepare end
activity.description: Execute an operation or series of operations to make the ends of a pipe suitable for connection.

activity.name: Produce primary spool piece
activity.description: Assemble the main part of a spool piece connecting pipes and other piping materials. This process forms simple connection such as welding straight pipes to flanges.

activity.name: Produce final spool piece
activity.description: Assemble a spool piece to its final form, connecting a primary spool piece, pipes and other piping materials.

activity.name: Inspect welding
activity.description: Examine and analyze welded part of prefabricated spool pieces for manufacturing defects in accordance with the inspection procedure. Welding is generally the most important inspection item for prefabricated piping.

activity.name: Inspect dimension
activity.description: Examine and analyze the dimensions of prefabricated spool pieces for manufacturing defects in accordance with the inspection procedure.

page.title: Complete and ship shop fabricated piping

activity.name: Clean prefabricated piping
activity.description: Process prefabricated spool pieces to remove weld sputter, rust and other debris from their surfaces, to be ready for painting and for shipping.

activity.name: Paint prefabricated piping
activity.description: Apply coatings of paint to the necessary parts of prefabricated spool pieces to protect them from rusting.

activity.name: Protect prefabricated piping
activity.description: Protect and pack prefabricated spool pieces to be ready for shipping.
activity.example: Protection of bevelled ends or flange faces using plastic caps, wood plates or adhesive tape is made to avoid damage during transportation and handling.

activity.name: Tag prefabricated piping
activity.description: Attach an identifying label to each prefabricated spool piece to distinguish it.

activity.name: Load prefabricated piping
activity.description: Place spool pieces on the transport for shipping to a plant.

icom.name: Assembly jigs and tools
icom.description: Miscellaneous fixtures, guides and tools that are used for assembling prefabricated piping, which make prefabrication works easy and accurate.

icom.name: As-built documents
icom.description: Site plans, detailed equipment descriptions, electrical instrumentation diagrams, and P&IDs that record the actual condition of a plant at a specific point in time.
icom.note: These documents aid in meeting government documentation and safety requirements. Frequently, they are simply corrections or modifications to existing design documents delivered to construction.

icom.name: Authorization plan
icom.description: High level plan, justification, and forecast for design and construction of a plant. The authorization plan describes how funds, people, and resources are to be allocated for the plant project.
icom.note: It is a document used internally and is sometimes called a white paper.

icom.name: Automation tools
icom.description: The collection of software and hardware tools used to assist the activities involved in the life cycle of a process plant.

icom.name: Basic laws
icom.description: Those elements of natural and human laws affecting any activity in the life cycle of a process plant.
icom.example: These laws include operating rules and guidelines as established by U.S. federal regulatory agencies such as the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

icom.name: Bending machine
icom.description: Machines that form curves in straight pipes.

icom.name: Bent pipe
icom.description: Pipes that are curved in accordance with the radii specified in piping prefabrication documents.

icom.name: Bids
icom.description: Commercial proposal by supplier for provision of equipment, supplies, or services.

icom.name: Capital appropriation
icom.description: Authorization of funding for capital project or expenditure.

icom.name: Change request
icom.description: A request made by an user of data to revise the original or current version of something due to errors, omissions, or other reasons, such as new requirements.
icom.note: A request is followed by review, analysis, and approval. Change requests are tracked in terms of cost and schedule (a kind of mini-project within project).
Change requests may be made against a supplier list, process, plant, procedure, and design basis.
Change request originators include construction and operations.

icom.name: Change request (design)
icom.description: A request made by an user of data to revise the original or current version of the design of something due to errors, omissions, or other reasons.

icom.name: Change request (plant)
icom.description: A request made by an user of data to revise the original or current version of the design of the plant due to errors, omissions, or other reasons.

icom.name: Change request (procedure)
icom.description: A request made by an user of data to revise the original or current version of a procedure due to errors, omissions, or other reasons.

icom.name: Change request (supplier list)
icom.description: A request made by an user of data to revise the original or current version of the supplier's list due to errors, omissions, or other reasons.

icom.name: Chemical properties
icom.description: Chemical data needed by the process engineer during design.

note.p: This data includes, but is not limited to:

icom.name: Cleaned spool piece
icom.description: Prefabricated spool pieces that have been processed to remove weld sputter, rust and other debris from their surfaces.

icom.name: Codes
icom.description: Widely recognized, accepted, and sometimes legally mandated rules that apply during the life-cycle of the plant. These rules govern life-cycle activities such as design, fabrication, and operation, and characteristics such as safety. Codes are consensus documents and specifications and are sometimes a subset of regulatory requirements.

icom.name: Commissioned plant
icom.description: A plant that has been proven to be operational through commissioning procedures.

icom.name: Commissioning procedures
icom.description: Step-by-step explanation of start-up actions required to commission the plant.

icom.name: Company requirements
icom.description: Those managerial decisions that place constraints on the operations of the company, that give direction or emphasis on areas for development, or that dictate decisions outside the local decision making paths. The embodiment of policies and regulations that govern the operations of a company.

icom.name: Construction design specification
icom.description: A contractual document that gives the criteria and standards to be used in the construction of the plant.
icom.example: The specification contents include detailed construction drawings, plant layout, equipment lists, isometric models, piping and instrumentation diagrams, specifications for the construction phase of the project, and pre-commissioning, acceptance and approval, and testing procedures.

icom.name: Construction documentation
icom.description: All information related to the construction of the process plant.
icom.example: Documentation includes as-built reports, equipment certification, nameplate information of installed equipment, operating manuals, testing procedures, field changes, and photographs of as-built units, modules, and plant.

icom.name: Construction plan
icom.description: A description of the method(s) to be used for building or fabricating a plant or plant item.

icom.name: Construction services
icom.description: Constructor activities and abilities to be used to construct the plant.

icom.name: Control requirements
icom.description: Requirements and criteria specified in operating procedures and safety requirements imposed on the mechanisms and systems that monitor and control plant operation.

icom.name: Corporate standards
icom.description: Procedures, instructions, or specifications that may be used in the execution of a plant project and are standardized within an organization. Corporate standards are not project specific, but may be used (and possibly customized) by a variety of projects. Corporate standards are developed over a long period of time as standard, recommended, or best practice.
icom.example: Kinds of standards include safety, design, and maintenance.

icom.name: Cutting machine
icom.description: Cutting machine of straight pipes. NC band saw machine is used for piping CAM system.

icom.name: Delivery dates
icom.description: Scheduled date for delivery of procured items to meet or support construction.

icom.name: Design basis
icom.description: A document provided by the plant owner or developed by the architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) contractors that establishes or defines the information and data that Plant engineering is to be based upon. It consists of guidelines and requirements, corporate standards, codes, references to regulatory agreements, form of deliverables, and plant or production capacity.

ul.li: plant product or output (type and capacity);

example.p: It also addresses performance objectives for the plant such as:

icom.note: Performance objectives usually take the form of a written document owned and maintained by the project team (consisting of members from the business, engineering, construction, and plant site).
The definition for design basis is from an owner's perspective.

icom.name: Design strategy
icom.description: A description of major steps required to complete enough design to obtain a budget estimate for business calculations as well as to begin the identification of process unknowns that may or may not require piloting. It encompasses building technology, mechanical technology, utility technology, automation technology, schedules, scope, standards and regulations, process definition, control philosophies, costs, benefits and timings, and project approach (e.g., architectural engineering, construction management, internal).

icom.name: Disassembled plant
icom.description: All equipment items remaining after the disposal of a process plant.

icom.name: Disposal documentation
icom.description: All information related to the disposal of the process plant including acceptance and approval procedures used in disposing all hazardous materials, residues, insulation, wiring, piping, vessels, rotating equipment, site cleanup and restoration reports, and photographs.

icom.name: Electrical, instrumentation and control design (final)
icom.description: The design of electrical, instrumentation and control of the plant, to its final state.

icom.name: Electrical, instrumentation and control documents
icom.description: All documents, information and drawings that are the result of the design activity for the electrical system and the instrumentation and control system within a plant. These documents provide a record of the electrical system and instrumentation and control system design.

icom.name: End preparation machine
icom.description: Machines to prepare ends of pipes suitable for connection.
icom.example: Beveling and finishing are two types of end preparations.

icom.name: End prepared pipe
icom.description: Pipes with ends that are prepared for connection, such as bevel end, screwed end or straight end.

icom.name: Energy
icom.description: All utilities required in the production of useful products through the operation of a process plant.

icom.name: Engineering design, construction and operation changes
icom.description: Changes to the design of the plant arising from errors, omissions, new requirements, or other reasons during plant design, construction, or operation.

icom.name: Equipment skeleton
icom.description: Skeleton design of equipment outline to be utilized for the design of layout and piping details.

icom.name: Environmental impact assessment
icom.description: Evaluation of project's or plant's affect on the environment.
icom.note: A report is usually required by an environmental regulatory agency before construction can begin.

icom.name: Equipment characteristics (functional)
icom.description: Describe or specify the functional requirements for the equipment: what it is supposed to do. They are items of information that describe: the service provided to the process by the equipment.
icom.example: For a pump, such information might include a descriptive name or title, such as 1502-B Condensate Return Pump B.

icom.name: Equipment characteristics (performance)
icom.description: Describe or specify the performance requirements for the equipment: how much it is supposed to do it. They are items of information that describe the effect that equipment has on the process or other operational information.
icom.example: For a pump, such information might include flow rate, total developed head, and efficiency.

icom.name: Equipment characteristics (process)
icom.description: A subset of equipment functional data that describe the contribution to the process desired from equipment. Such data is specified prior to the actual selection of specific equipment to fulfill the purpose.
icom.example: For a pump, such information might include flow rate, total developed head, and efficiency.

icom.name: Equipment characteristics (required)
icom.description: Needed functional, performance, physical, or process attributes of an item that have a name and measurable value.
icom.example: For a pump, such information might include flow rate, total developed head, and efficiency.

icom.name: Equipment id
icom.description: An identifier assigned to a piece of equipment.

icom.name: Equipment list
icom.description: A list of equipment in the process plant.

example.p: An equipment list includes, but not limited to:

ul.li: location (e.g., building, elevation, area, column row);
service requirements (e.g., air, water, structural base, electrical power, control circuitry);

icom.note: The equipment list may not include all equipment. It does not include miscellaneous equipment and devices (e.g., y-pattern strainers, inline flow meters, instruments) or valves.

icom.name: Guidelines and requirements
icom.description: Specifications, instructions, and mandates specified by management that shall be followed in the plant project. These guidelines and requirements may be project specific. Guidelines are more generally applicable than requirements, which tend to be specific in terms of what must be done.

note.p: Originators and users of guidelines and requirements are:
These categories are not mutually exclusive.

icom.name: Heat and mass calculations
icom.description: Calculations performed based on design basis, unit operations, fuel or materials in the process, along with associated chemical properties to optimize plant and operational cost.

icom.name: HVAC design documents
icom.description: All documents, information and drawings that are the result of the design activity for the HVAC system within a plant. These documents provide a record of the HVAC system design.

icom.name: Information databases
icom.description: Those elements of information collections comprising literature references, physical and transport properties, symbology sets, equipment specifications, and equipment costs that assist in the conception, design, construction, operation, and disposal of a process plant.

icom.name: Initial information
icom.description: Any knowledge available at the start of the process to build or modify a process plant.
icom.example: This includes information about the site, regulatory agreements, owner requirements, and approved suppliers.

icom.name: Innovation
icom.description: New ideas and concepts generated internally or through the public domain to solve problems or to enhance the quality of work.
icom.note: Some ideas and concepts may become goods, services, and systems that there is a societal requirement for. To some degree, innovation is fundamental to all activities involved with the process, however, particular emphasis is placed on activities that require generation of new ideas and concepts from abstract entities as inputs.

icom.name: Inspected spool piece
icom.description: Assembled spool pieces after they successfully have completed the inspection process.

icom.name: Inspection plan
icom.description: The description of anticipated activities necessary for surveillance of suppliers, fabricators, and assemblers to verify compliance to contractual specifications, codes, and good practice.
icom.note: The plan usually lists the items to be inspected, the place where the inspections are expected to occur, anticipated frequency of inspection and type of activity to be undertaken at each inspection. The reporting procedure for the surveillance results is usually included in the developed inspection plan.

icom.name: Inspection procedure
icom.description: The process steps, measurement items, allowances and other inpection tools and materials used to execute the inspection process.

icom.name: Inspection report
icom.description: Documentation of the results of inspection.

icom.name: Inspection requirements
icom.description: All requirements, regulations and codes that are applied at inspection.

icom.name: Inspection requirements (decommissioning)
icom.description: Requirements imposed by a regulatory agency related to the inspection of the plant during the decommissioning process.

icom.name: Inspection results
icom.description: Reports that result from inspection and supplier surveillance activities.

icom.name: Licensed technologies
icom.description: Patented or proprietary processes or design information purchased or licensed from an outside source, such as a process processor, supplier, or fabricator.
icom.note: This technology may range from laboratory synthesis data through unit operation process data to complete, detailed plant designs or equipment items and modules.

icom.name: Line schedule and list
icom.description: A subset of information presented on the P&ID, and possibly the heat and mass balance, that describes the characteristics of pipelines required for a given process.
icom.note: This information is used by the piping designer during the detail design. It is analogous to the equipment list.

icom.name: Manual and machine processing condition
icom.description: Manual or automatic machining parameter settings to process piping materials.
icom.example: Some processing conditions for a welding machine are volt, ampere, seal gas flow rate, or welding speed . Some processing conditions for an automatic cutting machine are end to end cut length, cutting speed, and end dimensions.

icom.name: Management authorizations and controls
icom.description: Management authorization, imperatives, directives, and procedures for initiating and executing plant management activities.

icom.name: Operating philosophy
icom.description: The plant owner's operational goals.
icom.example: Operational goals include methods of production, technology, plant safety, and plant availability.

icom.name: Operating procedures
icom.description: Documentation that covers many different phases and aspects of plant operation that is necessary to run the plant safely.

icom.name: Other piping materials
icom.description: Miscellaneous materials, except straight pipes, that are used for fabricating piping assemblies, and become parts of fabricated piping assemblies.

icom.name: Owner requirements
icom.description: An initial statement of plant requirements provided by the owner.
icom.note: Owner requirements are an aggregation of items such as design requirements and client general specifications. The owner requirements may be provided at any level of abstraction from very general to very specific.

icom.name: Packing materials
icom.description: Materials necessary for protecting prefabricated spool pieces during shipping.

icom.name: Painted spool piece
icom.description: Spool pieces with the necessary parts coated with paint to protect from rusting.

icom.name: Personnel
icom.description: The individuals responsible for performing the life-cycle activities of the process plant.
icom.example: These individuals include discipline experts, skilled workers, and labourers.

icom.name: Piping 3D model
icom.description: A 3-dimensional computer model of the spatial configuration of the piping in the plant.

icom.name: Piping and instrumentation diagram (P&ID)
icom.description: A schematic diagram that shows engineering details of the equipment, instruments, pipes, valves, and their connectivity and sequence.

icom.name: Piping and instrumentation diagram (AFD)
icom.description: The process definition is firm. Instrumentation needs to be added.

icom.name: Piping and instrumentation diagram (design)
icom.description: Instrumentation details are included. All lines and valves have been sized. All valving, vents and drains are included. Instrumentation and loops are indicated, but final instrumentation may not have been selected.

icom.name: Piping and instrumentation diagram (final)
icom.description: The complete P&ID has been approved for release by engineering for construction and has been stamped by a registered professional engineer. It is a last version of the design P&ID. It contains all changes that were incorporated during the physical design of the systems. It reflects the plant as it was, or will be, constructed.

icom.name: Piping and instrumentation diagram (preliminary)
icom.description: Conveys the flow of the fluids from equipment to equipment in the system. It shows the valves that are used to control the flow. The major fluid containing lines have been sized.

icom.name: Piping arrangement
icom.description: The 3D spatial configuration of the piping design in the plant.

icom.name: Piping inspection documents
icom.description: All documents, information and drawings that are the result of piping detail design and are used for piping inspection.

icom.name: Piping installation documents
icom.description: All documents, information and drawings that are the result of piping detail design and are used for piping installation.

icom.name: Piping material takeoff
icom.description: The collection of piping materials of the plant.

icom.name: Piping materials
icom.description: All necessary materials that are used when fabricating piping assemblies, and become parts of fabricated piping assemblies.

icom.name: Piping prefabrication documents
icom.description: All documents, information and drawings that are the result of piping detail design and are used for piping prefabrication.

icom.name: Piping route design
icom.description: The design of the path in which the piping is laid out between equipment items in the plant.
icom.note: The piping route is usually expressed by plan view only.

icom.name: Piping specification
icom.description: Consensus or mandate technical descriptions of piping that controls the design, prefabrication and fabrication of piping.

icom.name: Plant
icom.description: A portion of an installation (or the entire installation) required to operate to produce products.
icom.example: Products produced include chemicals, pharmaceuticals, electrical power, petroleum, and similar products.

icom.name: Plant design documentation
icom.description: All documents related to the process of designing the process plant.
icom.note: Plant design documents include the approved design methodologies, basic data describing physical properties and their correlations used in the design, kinetic data and kinetic models used in the design, corrosion data and methodology used in selecting materials of construction, supplier performance data, capital and operating cost estimates, and appropriations requests.

icom.name: Plant items
icom.description: An item or piece of equipment that may be used as a component of the plant.

icom.name: Plant life-cycle documentation
icom.description: The collection of all project management, design, contractual, regulatory, and disposal documents produced during the life cycle of a process plant.
icom.note: This includes all data retained past the end of the plant life cycle.
This is within the scope of ISO 15926-2:2003. This part of ISO 10303 support the input or output of data relevant to a particular stage in the life-cycle of a plant from a repository of such data.

icom.name: Plant operation and maintenance documentation
icom.description: The collection of documents relating to the operation and maintenance of process plant.
icom.note: These documents include operating records and plant data, safety and accident reports, maintenance reports, disposal records for all residual materials generated during the operation of the plant, and economic information related to product sales.

icom.name: Plant performance requirements
icom.description: A quantitative description of the quantity and quality of a product to be produced by the plant in a yearly time period.
icom.note: Performance requirements are usually stated as units of product per unit time. Additional qualifications are made regarding the quality of the Plant, such as time between major shutdowns for continuous processes, percent uptime required, and expected yield.

icom.name: Plant records
icom.description: The documentation of information related to plant disposal, restoration, turnover, and regulatory approvals.

icom.name: Plot plan
icom.description: The arrangement design of the main equipment, buildings and structures of the plant.
icom.note: The plot plan is usually expressed by plan view only.

icom.name: Plot plan (preliminary)
icom.description: An initial arrangement design of the main equipment, building and structures of the plant.

icom.name: Prefabricated piping products
icom.description: Spool pieces that are the final the products of prefabricator. These spool pieces have been prefabricated, inspected and packed, and become prefabricator's final products.

icom.name: Prefabricated spool piece
icom.description: Spool pieces in their final form prior to inspection.

icom.name: Pre-commissioned plant
icom.description: A plant that is completed and ready for check out. Mechanical systems are complete, transfer of ownership and operation remain.

icom.name: Primary spool piece
icom.description: Assemblies of the main parts of spool pieces that consist of pipes and other piping materials. Primary spool pieces are usually formed by simple connections, such as by welding straight pipes to flanges.

icom.name: Process control logic
icom.description: Prose or diagrammatic explanation of mechanisms or systems that monitor and control a process.

icom.name: Process control logic (preliminary)
icom.description: Initial prose or diagrammatic explanation of mechanisms or systems that monitor and control a process developed during conceptual process design.

icom.name: Process flow diagram (PFD)
icom.description: A schematic document describing the equipment units and their interconnections, major process control functions, and major stream characteristics including physical and transport properties, material flows, and energy flows.

icom.name: Processing machines and tools
icom.description: Various kind of machines and tools which are used for manufacturing prefabricated piping such as cutting machine, welding machine, jigs and tools.

icom.name: Procured item
icom.description: Plant item that has been obtained from a supplier for incorporation into the plant.

note.p: States or status of procured items include:

icom.name: Procurement schedule and material list
icom.description: A schedule that describes when procured materials will be received, and a list of procured materials and their quantities and other pertinent procurement information.

icom.name: Production schedule
icom.description: A time-based list of production tasks.

icom.name: Project authorizations and controls
icom.description: Management authorization, imperatives, directives, and procedures for initiating and executing project activities.

icom.name: Project control and approval documentation
icom.description: A set of documents that define the standard procedures, standard software modules, or standard forms adopted to ensure that all activities in the project comply with organizational constraints. The documents indicate how all activities are to be implemented and approved and identify all constraints that must be met.
icom.note: The constraints include financial limitations, accounting, legal and regulatory restrictions, socio-economic factors, and business practices throughout the plant life cycle.

icom.name: Project financial plan
icom.description: Document that states how much the plant will cost to construct, how it is to be paid for, and when payments are to be made. It is a general financing and cash flow document.

icom.name: Project-specific documents
icom.description: Procedures, standards, guidelines, specifications, and codes created specifically for the plant project. These documents may call out, add to, modify, or tailor a standard. Portions of these documents are derived from the design basis.
icom.note: Project-specific documents evolve through stages like P&IDs and other design documentation.

icom.name: Protected and packed spool piece
icom.description: spool pieces that are protected and packed to be ready for shipping.

icom.name: Purchase agreement
icom.description: Contract between two parties to provide a service or item for a designated payment.

icom.name: Purchase order
icom.description: A directive issued to suppliers to acquire materials.

icom.name: Qualified construction firms
icom.description: List of construction firms that are capable and acceptable to construct the plant.

icom.name: Received piping materials
icom.description: Straight pipe and other piping materials that are brought to the piping prefabricator that are used to prefabricate the piping.

icom.name: Regulatory agreements
icom.description: Mutual agreement between the owner or operators and regulatory agencies.

icom.name: Regulatory authorizations
icom.description: Approval from regulatory agencies to initiate activities.

icom.name: Regulatory requirements
icom.description: International, national or regional laws, codes, or standards that impact various activities related to the process plant.
icom.note: Regulatory requirements may apply to, but are not limited to, permitting, engineering, construction, operations and decommissioning.

icom.name: Repair order
icom.description: Directive to repair a rejected product after inspection.

icom.name: Request for management approval
icom.description: A document submitted to management requesting either approval to continue a particular activity of the project or requesting the procedure to use to solve a particular problem.
icom.note: Approval requests may, at times, include a request that the company appropriate monies for a particular activity.

icom.name: Residual materials
icom.description: All chemicals and equipment, excluding useful products, remaining in the environment at the end of the plant life cycle.

icom.name: Resources
icom.description: The technology, people, and tools used to carry out the plant life-cycle activities.

icom.name: Resources (existing)
icom.description: Currently available technology, people, and tools used to carry out the plant life-cycle activities.

icom.name: Safety and hazardous operations analysis
icom.description: The results of the evaluation of the plant design with respect to safety and hazardous operations. Identifies possible causes of faults and their consequences, and recommends remedies.

icom.name: Safety and hazardous operations analysis (preliminary)
icom.description: The initial results of the evaluation of the plant design with respect to safety and hazardous operations.

icom.name: Safety compliance reports
icom.description: Documentation of analyses and evaluations of the plant performed with respect to safety considerations.

icom.name: Safety system specification
icom.description: Job specific document related to plant safety.
icom.note: This specification may be developed from applying the design safety philosophy to plant design.

description.p: A time-based list of project tasks that describes:

ul.li: when it is supposed to happen;

icom.name: Schematic diagrams
icom.description: A physically non-dimensional, 2D graphical representation of the functional design of a system that does not (necessarily) encompass physical information.
icom.note: Schematic diagrams evolve through stages like P&IDs and other design documentation.

icom.name: Schematic diagrams (preliminary)
icom.description: An initial physically non-dimensional, 2D graphical representation of the functional design of a system that does not (necessarily) encompass physical information developed during conceptual plant design.

icom.name: Shipping report
icom.description: Documentation to notify customers of shipping information about the shipment of spool pieces.

icom.name: Short pipe
icom.description: Short straight pipes that are cut from straight pipes.

icom.name: Site information (existing)
icom.description: Information about the physical location where the plant will be constructed and the conditions of any plant on the site (if one exists).

ul.li: geological data, such as before and after terrain contours, and subterranean structure, and seismic activity;
meteorological data such as seasonal wind profile, precipitation, snowfall, and ambient temperature;

icom.note: A kind of site information included in the scope of this part of ISO 10303 is verified field dimensions. They are parameters that specify the physical and spatial characteristics of an existing item or component in a plant that have been verified by measurements taken by a second, independent agency. For example, field dimensions provided by the Plant owner for piping tie-in locations (coordinate locations and sizes) are considered as "verified" when duplicated by the AEC representative. If discrepancies are discovered during verification of the field dimensions, the initial and verification measurement processes must be repeated to assure verified dimensions.
Existing plant conditions are the characteristics of the existing plant(s) relevant to the revamp, retrofit, or expansion Plant project.

icom.name: Spatial layout
icom.description: The detailed arrangement design of equipment, buildings and structures of the plant.
icom.note: The layout is usually expressed by both plan and elevation view.

icom.name: Societal requirements
icom.description: The expressed need or demand by society, on either a local, national, or global scale, for products, services, or processes.
icom.note: In some instances, a market study may project the expected demand or price of a product or service required by some element of society.

icom.name: Specifications and standards
icom.description: Consensus or mandated technical descriptions of plant hardware or systems that control the design or construction of a plant.

icom.name: Spool piece (for repairing)
icom.description: Assembled spool pieces after the welds have completed successfully the inspection process.

icom.name: Spool piece (after welding inspection)
icom.description: Defective assembled spool pieces returned to the prefabrication process for repair after inspection.

icom.name: Standards documents
icom.description: Consensus or mandated technical records of requirements and specifications for plant hardware or systems that control the design or construction of a plant.

icom.name: Standard practice
icom.description: Fabrication practices standardized by a company, industry, national, or international standards organization that are used for manufacture.

icom.name: Standard procurement procedure
icom.description: The steps and materials to execute the procurement process that are standardized by a manufacturer.

icom.name: Starting materials
icom.description: All necessary equipment components or consumable goods necessary to construct and operate the process plant for the production of useful products.

icom.name: Status
icom.description: A report of the current state of a task, design, action, or schedule. It is a quality assurance feedback mechanism.

icom.name: Straight pipe
icom.description: Circular straight tubes that are used for fabricating piping, and become parts of fabricated piping assemblies.

icom.name: Stream data
icom.description: Chemical composition, physical state, and mass quantities of process flows.

icom.name: Structure design documents
icom.description: All documents, information and drawings that are the result of the design activity for the structures within a plant. These documents provide a record of the structural design of the plant.

icom.name: Supplier documentation
icom.description: Drawings, manuals, calculations, etc. received from a company concerning items procured from the company, that provides information concerning design details or performance of the procured items.

note.p: Statuses assigned to supplier documentation include:

ul.li: certified (information from the supplier is warranted to correctly describe the as-delivered functional or physical data);

icom.name: Suppliers list
icom.description: A list of companies that provide commodities or services to an organization.

note.p: Kinds or statuses of supplier lists include:

icom.name: System design (final)
icom.description: System design, expressed by flow and control information and equipment performance data, to its final state.

icom.name: System design (preliminary)
icom.description: At the conceptual level, this is an initial definition and representation of the physical components or items of the system.

icom.name: System layout (preliminary)
icom.description: At the conceptual level, this is an initial definition and representation of the spatial configuration or arrangement of the system, showing all the major components of the system.

icom.name: System layout and design
icom.description: The definition and representation of the physical components or items and spatial configuration of the system in sufficient detail to support construction.
icom.note: This definition results from the use of the system design basis, P&IDs, specifications, and other documentation or information.
The definition of the term "system" is broader than common usage, e.g., it encompasses structural systems.

note.p: System layout and designs can be viewed or categorized according to the following breakdowns:

ul.li: Piping and instrumentation diagram (includes piping connectivity and sequencing).

icom.example: The final HVAC spatial information system design and layout will specify the definition, physical dimensions, location coordinates, and characteristics for all HVAC components that occupy space in the Plant. Only those physical dimensions, location coordinates, and characteristics required to specify the spatial instance of each component are included in this definition.

icom.name: System layout and design (preliminary)
icom.description: The initial definition and representation of the physical components or items and spatial configuration of the system.

icom.name: Tagged spool piece
icom.description: Spool pieces that have identifying labels attached to distinguish them.

icom.name: Tagged spool piece
icom.description: Spool pieces that have identifying labels attached to distinguish them.

icom.name: Threading machine
icom.description: Machines to prepare screw ends at the ends of pipes.

icom.name: Time and cost estimate
icom.description: Projected or forecasted cost and length of time to design, produce, or procure a plant item, obtain a service, or achieve some goal.

icom.name: Unit operations
icom.description: Design basis and owner requirements that define the basis for conceptual process design.

icom.name: Useful products
icom.description: The materials or energy generated through the operation of the process plant that are sold to customers for a profit.

icom.name: Weld inspection report
icom.description: Documentation of the results of inspection of individual welds.

icom.name: Welding machine
icom.description: Welding machines to assemble pipes and other piping materials, to produce primary spool pieces which have usually simple form, such as straight pipe plus flange, single axis rotated welding machine.
